properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow for the New Year... A low pressure system will intensify over the Maritimes on Wednesday, bringing 10 to 15 centimetres of snow over the northern shore and the Parc de la Gaspésie. Moderate to strong northwesterly winds will develop Wednesday afternoon and evening and will cause blowing snow over exposed areas. Accumulating snow and poor visibility will make driving conditions difficult in this period of festivities. Please consider modifying any non essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T12:42:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-30T20:43:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3938535390.2019
Area: Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Murdochville area, Mont-Albert area, Grande-Rivière - Cascapédia area
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Brief, but intense snowfall expected to develop this morning. Flurries will develop early this morning. A brief period of heavy snow is expected later this morning. Strong wind gusts of up to 70 km/h are also anticipated. The combination of heavy snow and strong winds will result in reduced visibility. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T23:43:34-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T07:44:34-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1609272902.2019

Northerly winds gusting to 50 km/h will also produce reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and strong winds could affect travel on New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Locally higher amounts possible, especially over Prince County. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 70 km/h, possibly higher. Locations: All of Prince Edward Island. Time span: Tuesday afternoon into early Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Tuesday afternoon and could mix with or changeover to ice pellets with a risk of freezing rain before changing to rain near midnight then ending early Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds potentially gusting up to 70 km/h or higher will develop Tuesday evening then diminish Wednesday morning. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact travel across the province on New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to PEstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #PEStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T18:32:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T02:33:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3954598059.2019
Area: Kings County P.E.I., Queens County P.E.I., Prince County P.E.I.
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A frontal system approaching southern BC will bring heavy snow to the Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt. Snow will begin this evening with the snow level near 900 metres. The snow level will rise on Tuesday morning to near the summit at which point the snow will become heavy and wet. On Tuesday evening the wet snow will change to rain as the snow level rises above the summit. The highest snowfall will be near the summit with total accumulation of 20 to 30 cm expected by Tuesday evening. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T17:12:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T01:13:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1412315977.2019
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Gusty winds tonight. Gusty winds up to 65 kilometres per hour will continue over the regions through this evening and may cause further power outages due to the ice accumulation on trees and structures. The winds should gradually diminish overnight. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain and ice pellets tonight. Freezing rain or ice pellets will continue until midnight. Overnight a change to flurries is expected however freezing drizzle is also possible. Dense fog patches are also possible. Ice accumulations tonight may add another 2 to 5 mm of ice and additional power outages are possible. Poor travel conditions can be expected tonight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Accumulating snow to make travel difficult on New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 2 to 10 mm. Locations: Central to southern New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday morning into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Tuesday morning. Snow will gradually change to a brief period of freezing rain or ice pellets and then to rain over southern and eastern New Brunswick Tuesday night. The timing and combination of mixed precipitation will impact travel across much of the province on New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T19:03:50-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow and strong winds expected on New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Total rainfall: 2 to 5 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 to possibly 90 km/h. Locations: Iles-de-la-Madeleine Time span: Late Tuesday evening into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop Tuesday evening and persist into the overnight period and taper to shower or flurries early Wednesday morning. Strong east or southeast winds potentially gusting to 80 km/h or higher will develop Tuesday evening and persist overnight before diminishing later Wednesday morning, reducing visibility at times in blowing snow. The timing and combination of snow and strong winds could impact travel on the islands later New Year's Eve or New Year's Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T18:32:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T02:33:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3209343039.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected on New Year's Day. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: most of Newfoundland. Time span: overnight Tuesday night through Wednesday evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to develop over southwestern Newfoundland Tuesday night and spread across the Island on Wednesday. This could result in poor driving conditions on New Year's Day. The snow will likely change to rain along the south coast and southern Avalon Peninsula. Precipitation will taper off Wednesday evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected on New Year's Eve. Locations: central to northern New Brunswick. Time span: Tuesday morning to Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow will begin in the southwest Tuesday morning and spread to the northeast by Tuesday afternoon. Central and eastern parts of the province could see a period of ice pellets or freezing rain or a changeover to rain late Tuesday night before tapering off to flurries on Wednesday. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and ice pellets changing to rain along with strong winds expected for New Year's Eve. Total snowfall: 2 cm over southwestern Nova Scotia to 10 cm in the north, possibly higher over the Cape Breton Highlands. Total rainfall: 5 to 20 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 70 to 80 km/h. Locations: All of Nova Scotia. Time span: Tuesday morning into Wednesday morning. Remarks: Snow or rain is expected to develop Tuesday morning over southwestern Nova Scotia then spread to all regions of the province by Tuesday evening. Snow will mix with ice pellets and there continues to be a risk of freezing rain before the changeover to rain. Strong southeast winds gusting to 70 to possibly 80 km/h will develop Tuesday afternoon and evening then diminish overnight. The timing and combination of mixed precipitation and strong winds could impact travel in parts of the province on New Year's Eve. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T18:31:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-31T02:32:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1521147860.2019

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A robust frontal system is sliding south over the Interior of BC. Light snow will begin this evening over West Kootenay and Kootenay Pass. Snow will intensify early Tuesday morning. Total snowfall accumulation over Kootenay Pass is expected to be 20 to 30 cm. For the West Kootenay region, the highest accumulations are expected over higher terrain and will amount to 20 to 30 cm storm total. The heavy snow is expected to ease overnight Tuesday. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for tonight. Bands of heavy snow will affect the area through to Tuesday morning. Visibilities will be significantly reduced under the heaviest bands of snow. Total snowfall accumulations near 10 cm and locally 15 cm are possible by Tuesday morning. Travel is likely to be affected across the area. Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A frontal system pushing across the BC Interior is spreading snow to the North Columbia, West Columbia and Rogers Pass. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected overnight with further accumulations of 20 to 30 cm possible through Tuesday night. The heavy snow is expected to ease by Wednesday morning. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T14:53:42-00:00

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, continues. A frontal system moving southwards down the BC Coast will continue to give heavy rain to the coastal sections of the Central Coast and West Vancouver Island tonight and Tuesday. Storm totals well in excess of 100 mm are expected through Tuesday evening. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain is expected or occurring. More freezing rain across the regions expected tonight. Precipitation will transition to flurries or showers this evening. Dense fog patches are also possible. Additional power outages are possible. ### Ice build-up may cause tree branches to break. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Wreckhouse Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds are expected or occurring. Maximum gusts: southeasterly up to 110 km/h. Time span: overnight Tuesday night until Wednesday afternoon. Remarks: Strong southeasterly winds will develop Tuesday night with gusts to 110 km/h by Wednesday morning. Winds will ease and shift to southwesterly Wednesday afternoon. ### Very strong winds may push your vehicle around especially on roads through mountain passes and along deep valleys. Wreckhouse wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-31T18:53:47-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. A storm tracking across the northern interior this evening will continue to bring heavy snow to Pine Pass and Williston. 5 to 9 cm of snow has fallen over the region. Additional 5 to 10 cm snowfall is expected tonight. Snow will taper off to a few flurries or rain showers early Tuesday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A robust frontal system is sliding south over the Interior of BC. Light snow will begin this evening over West Kootenay and Kootenay Pass. Snow will intensify early Tuesday morning. Total snowfall accumulation over Kootenay Pass is expected to be 20 to 30 cm. For the West Kootenay region, the highest accumulations are expected over higher terrain and will amount to 20 to 30 cm storm total. The heavy snow is expected to ease overnight Tuesday. ### Poor weather conditions may contribute to transportation delays. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-31T14:56:27-00:00
